title.narrative: World Bank's Umbrella Trust Fund on Jobs
World Bank's Umbrella Trust Fund on Jobs

description.narrative:
Insatsen omfattar ett stöd till Världsbankens ”Umbrella Trust Fund on Jobs” (UTF Jobs) 2015-2017 om totalt 60 MSEK. Världsbanken har två övergripande mål fram till 2030: (1) att utrota extrem fattigdom genom att minska andelen människor som lever på mindre än $ 1,25 per dag till högst 3% och; (2) att bidra till välstånd för alla genom att främja inkomster och ekonomisk tillväxt för de fattigaste 40% i varje land.
Det övergripande målet för UTF Jobs är att stödja utformningen och genomförandet av Världsbankens sysselsättningsstrategi. Denna strategi syftar till att förbättra förutsättningar för produktiva arbetstillfällen för arbetstagare över hela världen, bidra till att utrota fattigdom och öka det gemensamma välståndet. För detta krävs integrerade verktyg och lösningar som underlättar för den privata sektorns skapande av nya arbetstillfällen, att öka produktiviteten av befintliga arbeten och att stötta individer - däribland unga människor och kvinnor – i att få ett jobb.
Insatsens mål är: 1) att utveckla sysselsättningsdata och diagnostiska verktyg; 2) att bedriva forskning och s.k. ”impact evaluations” för identifierade sysselsättningsutmaningar (t.ex. skapande av arbetstillfällen i konfliktländer och kortsiktiga kompromisser mellan produktivitetstillväxt och skapande av arbetstillfällen); 3) att utforma integrerade sysselsättningsstrategier i olika landkontexter och i partnerskap med den privata sektorn; 4) att stötta länder i införandet av innovativa lösningar för att skapa arbetstillfällen genom rådgivning, samordnande och finansiella tjänster; 5) att hjälpa till att bygga kapacitet hos Världsbankens kunder för att samla in och analysera data och modeller, samt att implementera diagnostiska verktyg, strategier och program - i syfte att bygga ansvarsutkrävande och hållbarhet; och 6) att utveckla partnerskap mellan utövare inom området och den privata sektorn - för att påverka utformningen och stödja genomförandet av ovanstående åtgärder.
UTF Jobs har valt att organisera ovanstående aktiviteter runt fem sammankopplade fönster, som i sin tur svarar mot behoven av Världsbankens olika delar liksom regionavdelningarna, de tematiska avdelningarna (”Globala Practices”) och de fem tvärområdena ("Cross Cutting Solution Areas"): 1. Diagnos, data och analys 2. Sysselsättningsskapande genom privatsektorn (Let’s Work-programmet). 3. Ungdomssysselsättning ("Solutions 4 Youth Employment—S4YE"). 4. Sysselsättning i konfliktländer och sviktande stater. 5. Forskning kring sysselsättning
Sida bedömer att fondens mål är väl i linje med gällande strategier och policyramverk. GECO har under en längre tid velat komplettera sin portfölj kring sysselsättningsfrågorna och det bedöms att denna insats väl kompletterar det globala stödet till den Internationella Arbetsorganisationen (ILO) och WIEGO (Women in Informal Employment: Globalizing and Organizing). I nuläget finns inga ytterligare stöd inom området planerade. Bedömningen är att Sida med detta stöd har en god täckning av sysselsättningsfrågorna globalt, samt att fonden väl kopplar till bilaterala och regionala insatser inom området.
Mervärdet av ett stöd till Världsbanken, i förhållande till de ovan nämnda stöden, är dess erfarenhet av att arbeta med storskaliga marknadsprogram samt med den privata sektorn. Banken har ett tydligare fokus på efterfrågesidan av arbetsmarknaden än exempelvis ILO. Världsbanken har också ett tydligare mandat att arbeta med den informella sektorn på en övergripande nivå, i förhållande till ILO som är mer bunden till den s.k. "decent work"-agendan.

The objective of the MDTF is to support the design and implementation of the World Bank Group’s jobs strategy, which aims to help design and deliver comprehensive, integrated and high impact jobs strategies for all relevant sectors in client countries; and to advance global knowledge about the most effective policies and actions for sustainable jobs, especially for the most vulnerable groups.

description.narrative: The work under the World Banks Multi-Donor Trust Fund (MDTF) for Jobs addresses the global and normative level through their work to advance global knowledge about the most effective policies and actions for sustainable jobs, especially for the most vulnerable groups, as well as the national institutional level through their support to design and implementation of jobs strategies in client countries. The MDTF Jobs fund was established in 2014 and thus far, it has funded over 100 activities, across 40 countries, 6 regions, 10 WBG Global Practices (GPs) and the IFC, through its five operational windows, and it has reached its target for all but one area in the results framework from 2015. The Jobs Group estimates that 41, 182 beneficiaries have been reached through direct MDTF-interventions, such as support to labour market matching programmes, entrepreneurship promotion interventions and youth employment programmes. In addition, the MDTF also support and leverage a number of other World Bank lending operations from a jobs perspective through which an additional 4.8 million beneficiaries is estimated to have been reached indirectly by the MDTF-grant. The nature of the results and development for the beneficiaries reached are, however, not explicitly reported. In 2019, the fund focused on concluding its first phase and started preparing for its second phase (2020-2024). Concluding the first phase meant delivering on the agreed 2019 workplan, with the aim to take stock of activities from the first phase and ensure that diagnostic work, lessons and experiences from operationalising jobs interventions were taken up as global public goods within and beyond the WBG. Concluding the first phase also entailed continued work with ongoing country level interventions. Below are examples of achievements and results at both global and national level from concluding the first phase. Global knowledge products Jobs Solution Notes [GLOB/NORM]: The MDTF team developed 6 Solutions Notes based on a broad, consultative process, synthesizing findings from MDTF-funded activities. The 6 Solutions Notes are based on evidence from research, impact evaluations, pilots, and operations and incorporate detailed feedback from within the Bank and from MDTF donors, and cover the following topics: - Adapting Jobs Policies and Program in the Face of Accelerated Technological Change - Agriculture, Jobs, and Value Chains in Africa Designing Small and Medium Enterprise (SME) Programs for More Jobs - Adapting Skills Training to Address Constraints to Women’s Participation - Jobs Interventions for Young Women in the Digital Economy - Supporting Jobs in Situations of Fragility, Conflict, and Violence (FCV) Jobs Indicator Database (JOIN) [GLOB/NORM]: JOIN is a global statistical resource on jobs for WB staff and beyond including policymakers, that was launched in 2019. It is a Global Jobs Indicator Data Bank that integrates jobs indicators along key labor market dimensions relevant for policy making. In the first months after launch, the JOIN data topics website received more than 11,500-page views. The dataset has been accessed by teams working on jobs related analysis and topics across the World Bank as well as from external users, including academia. The Global Jobs Indicators are systematically being used in the World Bank’s Jobs Diagnostic tools and for country level reports. They inform World Bank Systematic Country Diagnostics (SCDs) and Country Economic Memoranda (CEM). JOIN is being used for World Bank reports, concept notes, briefings, presentations and blogs. The World Bank Gender data portal has a link to JOIN. Jobs Core Courses [GLOB/NORM]: To support capacity building for job creation, the Jobs Group organized two training courses as a part of GP-wide Social Protection and Jobs Core Courses in 2019: Jobs, Labor and Migration (JLM) and Jobs Diagnostics and Solutions (JDS). The courses – attended by 106 students - provided hands-on training with tools and techniques to develop integrated, multi-sectoral jobs strategies. The audience for the JLM course comprised operational and research staff working in labor mobility and development, employment policies, informality, technical and vocational training, skills development, youth employment, and related policy areas. The audience for the JDS course, based on knowledge gained from conducting Jobs Diagnostics in over 40 countries, comprised technical and high-level staff engaged in or planning a Jobs Diagnostics in their country or region. This included economists, analysts, and researchers working on economic growth, macro-economic policy, national budgeting and planning, economic forecasting, and related areas. Participants also included donor and development partner counterparts. An outcome of the JDS pilot course was the creation of the Jobs Diagnostics and Solutions Community of Practice (JDS CoP). This is a knowledge sharing and learning platform for officials, development practitioners, researchers and WBG staff involved in developing cross-sector Jobs Strategies for countries, regions, and municipalities. The CoP is a volunteer member group which develops and disseminates data-driven tools, knowledge products, and global datasets through a discussion forum. Country level examples In Mozambique the fund finances four major components of the “Let’s Work Mozambique” work program: (i) jobs diagnostic and input to policy dialogue, (ii) value chain analysis, (iii) job pilots, and (iv) a knowledge-sharing platform for government, private sector, and development partner stakeholders. The objective is to promote creation of private sector jobs through a value chain–based approach, increase the productivity of existing jobs, and help connect people to jobs. During 2019, the project conducted an evaluation of a private sector labor market matching service for informal workers, and with in-depth, in-country expert studies of key value chains: cashew, cassava, sesame, pigeon pea, plantation forestry, and “green” construction. The work is conducted in collaboration with the Government of Mozambique and the main counterpart for the program is the Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF), but the Ministry of Labor is also involved in the work on developing a Jobs Strategy Note and the Ministry of Agriculture is engaged in the value chain analysis and advocacy work. [NAT/INST] In Georgia the fund contribute to deepen the jobs impact of a WB project focused on technology adoption. The grant will engage global expertise to support Georgia’s Innovation and Technology Agency (GITA) to design a randomized controlled trial (RCT) on technology adoption and its impacts on job creation, to improve understanding of the implications of ICT adoption and e-commerce on job growth and job creation by firms. Other stakeholders involved included the local municipalities, internet service providers, and community organizations participating in the program being evaluated. The funds engagement in the project also contribute to generate evidence to inform global policies. [NAT/INST] In Jordan the fund support an entrepreneurship pilot to promote economic opportunities for Jordanians and Syrians. The pilot will promote innovative entrepreneurship opportunities to both Jordanians and Syrians to create jobs, increase refugees’ contributions to the host economy, and incubate the future post-conflict Syrian economy in Jordan. The pilot have significant bearing on youth and gender as over half of Syrian refugees are female and 81 percent are below age 35; Jordan has one of the highest youth unemployment rates in the region, with a female youth unemployment rate of 51 percent compared with the male youth unemployment rate of 27 percent. Thus far, a mini pilot with about 100 entrepreneurs and potential entrepreneurs, both Syrians and Jordanians, has been conducted and an online networking platform has been enhanced to promote Jordanian and Syrian Refugee Entrepreneurship (jedad.com), and the platform currently hosts about 1500 businesses and is the largest networking platform in MENA. [NAT/INST] In Liberia the fund support an Impact Evaluation within a project focused on promoting self-employment and entrepreneurship in fragile and conflict affected states. The Impact Evaluation focuses on the Government of Liberia’s Youth Opportunities Programme, and specifically the Small Business Support component, to assess return on investment to integrating skills training with start-up grants versus provision of start-up grants alone to youth business groups. This, to enable the government to better and more cost-efficiently promote self-employment and entrepreneurship among youth. [NAT/INST] In addition to the global and country level work, during 2019 the WB Jobs Group also developed a new approach to supporting large scale jobs-relevant operational lending across the WB and IFC, which will be adopted for the second phase of the MDTF Jobs. The approach goes under the name of 'Supporting Effective Jobs Lending at Scale' (SEJLS) and aims at scaling up WB lending operations at country level targeting jobs outcomes, advancing the jobs measurement agenda as well as external partnerships. This development is driven by demand from client government in IBRD and donors alike. As part of a transition period from phase one to phase two 15 pilots were launched during 2019 with this approach applied, funded by a remaining 5 MUSD from the first phase. These include strengthening the theory of change, design, implementation and measurement of jobs outcomes for lending operations on for example agriculture in Bangladesh, Ethiopia and South Sudan, environmental operations in Cambodia, and gender operations in Albania. Sida is currently appraising the full proposal for the second phase.
